Authors: Janusz Blaszkowski, Gerard Chwat, Anna Goralska
Title:
Acaulospora ignota and Claroideoglomus hanlinii, two new
species of arbuscular mycorrhizal fungi (Glomeromycota) from Brazil and
Cuba
Keywords:
distribution, molecular phylogeny, morphology, sand
dunes
Abstract:
Morphological studies of spores and mycorrhizal structures
and phylogenetic analyses of sequences of the partial small subunit rRNA
gene, the whole internal transcribed spacer rDNA region, including the
5.8S rRNA gene, and the partial large subunit rRNA gene of two
arbuscular mycorrhizal fungi (Glomeromycota) indicated they are
undescribed species, one of the genus Acaulospora, and the second of
Claroideoglomus. The first species, here named A. ignota, is
distinguished morphologically by yellow-coloured, relatively small
(65â80 Âµm diam when globose) spores whose upper surface of the
structural laminate spore wall layer is ornamented with inconspicuous
warts or flattened elevations usually deteriorating and disappearing
with age. The most distinguishing features of the second species, C.
hanlinii, are its relatively small (45â90 Âµm diam when globose) and
dark-coloured (olive yellow) spores with a simple, 2-layered spore wall,
of which the inner structural laminate layer 2 may by much thicker than
that in other known Claroideoglomus spp. The occasional and pale
staining of spore wall layer 1 in Melzerâs reagent is also distinctive
in the species. Both species were grown in single-species pot cultures
established from spores extracted from pot trap cultures with mixtures
of rhizosphere soils and roots of plants colonizing maritime sand dunes
near Natal, Brazil (A. ignota) and Varadero, Cuba (C. hanlinii). These
are the only sites of occurrence of both fungi known in the world to
date, which also confirmed comparisons of their sequences with those
deposited in available databases.
